reviewText: This game provides almost everything that I would want from an MMO. However, there are a few downsides. I'll start with the bad first.\n\nFirst off is the Vim System. It is kind of a negative thing for the game, but I can understand why it was put in. Vim is sort of like your crafting stamina, and it unlocks when one of your skills reaches 16. After you hit that point, everything you do when it comes to that specific skill will take up Vim points. Now, they do regenerate over time, but it's like every other game that has energy regeneration: few minutes at a time, and you only get one point back at a time. That wouldn't be so bad if you didn't need mass amounts for quests. The more you craft at a time, the more you use (e.g. one at a time for one Vim, or 50 for 150 Vim.) Gathering only takes one for each click, and sometimes you get three items instead of one, so that's not too bad. The biggest issue with this is that it greatly limits what you can do in the game each day. Sure, there are refills that you can buy (with in game tokens that you can earn, no real money required) and perks that cut down on how much is cut out, but if you don't have enough tokens or those perks yet, things can slow down pretty quickly. There are small free" refills that you can get to drop

reviewText:
The game should be renamed: Clickers and Heroes
or Grinding Heroes

At first glance the game is fairly cute and suitable for children. This is true and a positive thing.

But the core gameplay is a brutal GrindAndClickFest with agressive Pay to play concept: even the training missions are about craft 50 items... what means: you sit in the front of the monitor and click in every 3 seconds 50 times.
Also, this game is about epic grinding. Really, there are no challenges in the game, the loot and the resources are easy to reach BUT: you have to spend long minutes and hours just to click and click and click on the same spot to have the necessary resources.

All the gameplay is about just clicking and waiting, clicking and waiting, clicking and waiting.... while there are mechanics to reduce this tedioum, everything points to the shop.

Honesntly, if there would be a reasonable priced monthly fee to eliminate this click fest concept I would gladly pay for it (because I like the world and the relatively simple gameplay, and again the relatively non violent MMO concept). But at it's current state, the game really tries to enforce me to pay with the nasty I will make your clicker finger suffer if you dont pay" method. What I really don't like and I won't bend. Instead of that

reviewText:
While this is not the worst MMO out there, it certainly isn't one of the best.

Here's a Quick Look video of my tragic adventure in this game. All of what I descibed below is in there, though some parts edited for your sanity and bugs in the game. Even though it's long, I'll still call it a quick look since it's an MMO. Feel free to skip around if you want a general idea, or just read the short and dirty summary below.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0-bUgaTg8yc&list=UUsGKrLHOxr2113efbnkp5MA

I'll start off with saying that the first thing you do in this game is get plopped down in a tiny starter area and get asked to kill wolves. Pretty typical right? Well as I went to fight the most docile wolves apparently terrorizing the town, I got introduced to the combat system. You have to stay perfectly still and click buttons, and I STRESS perfectly still. If you move, you cancel your auto-attack. If you turn slightly, you also cancel your attack. Heck, even if you press the attack again, it cancels the attack and you have to wait for the ability to go off cooldown. If that's what the game is like right from the beginning, I can only dread what it's like late game.

But combat really isn't the main focus of this. Crafting and socializing is. So I excused the dated and poor combat system and continued my journey. What I found out was that you can infinitely gather from nodes that require no effort to get to. It didn't even encourage exploration. Not that there was much to explore. You play in linear zones that push you along a path. But hey, maybe the crafting was where this game shined...

Boy, was I wrong. It was as basic as the gathering. You click on the recipe, and let the game take care of the rest for you. There wasn't even some sort of minigame to make it more engaging. It was just a droll experience of clicking buttons and farting around.

Alright, well perhaps the social part was the point of this. I wanted to try chatting to some peeps, but I rarely encountered another person. And when I did, they were doing the same boring stuff I was doing. But regardless, counting on the community to make your boring game more enjoyable isn't what developers should be hoping for. So it fell flat for me again. Even more when I discovered there wasn't a /dance command. C'mon now? No dancing?

But I dredged on. And I found several bugs along the way. Sure, I understand most MMO's have them. The games are so big, it's kind of expected. But I don't think you should be encountering so many in the starting zone, probably the most tested place of them all. Why did my character leap into the water and flop like a fish when I asked him just to fish? Why are there strange black squares following me on the ground everywhere I go? Why is a fenced area full of hens called a sheep plot? Heck, I even had a game breaking bug that kicked me out of the game and corrupted my video footage. But even after all that, I suffered through this game some more to give a better review.

Most of the quests. if not all, where simple fetch quests. All you had to do was go to a place sometimes a few feet away to complete them. It's like the quest givers themselves couldn't be arsed to play their own game. The animations are terrible too. Sure, some of the attacks look flashy, but rarely do they actually connect to what you're supposed to be attacking. Walking sideways is the most laughable thing in this game. It was so bad, I actually enjoyed doing it. I even fell off a cliff and my guy was as stiff as a board all the way down. It's just not polished at all.

And when I finally reached the last boss of the tutorial, Grimbad the Deadly or something rediculous like that, I just walked right up to him and stared at him. He didn't even attack me. The big bad boss just aimelessly wandered around, looking for a way to escape his cruel fate.

That just broke me. There is just no immersion in this game. I couldn't get a feel for it, and the point of MMO's is to lose you in their world, which this game failed miserably at.

But after being so negative, I'll list a few positives. I like the jumping flips. You go so damn high when you get a boost from some boots. I like that the game's quest helper tells you exactly what to do, even if it does hold your hand too much by saying where you can get stuff. And, umm, some of the bugs were kind of funny? Eh, I guess that counts as something.

So all in all, even if this game is free, I can't recommend it. There are plenty of better MMO's out there, some free as well. Don't waste your time here.

reviewText:
With the new update to Villagers and Heroes: Reborn, a lot of the annoyances of this title have been removed. The much-hated VIM system has been kicked out, and a lot of new features have been added. If you played this game before, you should definitely retry this game.

If you never played this game before, then Villagers and Heroes is a fun MMORPG. Quests, Crafting, Levels, Housing, it's all in the game. There's a lot of maps to explore.

Villagers and Heroes: Reborn is made by a small development team, but they delivered an epic update.

reviewText:
People keep saying that the controls feel like a facebook type game and the like.  Well, this game WAS actually on facebook a long time ago.  I played this game a few years back and when I log into facebook, I can still see this game on my list.  While it has improved from it's facebook days somewhat, it's still not up to par.  It is creative in it's own right (Bughunting as a profession!?) and it does offer player housing and growing stuff in your garden and caring for animals.  I do like having some form of simulation aspects in my games.

But it is really clunky, and it has a lot of 'seen that, did it in another mmo!' type of vibe.  It's also not graphically appealing and for the most part I kept the sound off.

It's playable and you might get some entertainment out of it, but there is definitely better out there.

reviewText:
This is a nice game, with funhy cartoon-like graphics and a sence of humor. As many others have already commented, it is a next-gen Runescape. So if you are in to Runescape, go ahead and try it.
If you don't like Runescape or don't even know what it is, then DON'T try this!

Unfortunately, in my opinion, the game is heavily Pay to Play!!
From the 35 hours I have on record, the 30 or so were consumed on clicking on trees, mineral nodes and anvils in order to level up crafting skills..And I managed to get them to level 15...I can't imagine how much time it would take me to get to 50...Of course, you can speed up the process by using harvesters, but you have to pay real money to get them! ;)

Travel pads (the way to teleport between areas) require travel stones. You get 1 free for every travel pad you discover (I got 7). If you are 3 areas away from the main city, you have to either travel on foot or use teleport..After 4-5 freebies, you HAVE to pay to get Travel Stones..

It also has a farmville simulation! Plant. water, collect crops in order to level up your villager skills. At least crops deliver some good in-game cash...

There are lots of other examples of situations that you have to pay in order to avoid the EXTREMELY OUTRAGEOUS LONG and TEDIOUS grinding you need to do.

reviewText:
Full Video Review and Gameplay - http://youtu.be/HEKJWlgYY_s


Let's talk gameplay, those familiar with traditional MMO's like World of Warcraft will have no trouble in jumping straight into this one. Character creation is simple and straightforward, sadly there’s not much in the way of customization here, just a few sliders with generic options. There are four classes to choose from, Warrior, Wizard, Hunter and Priest. Each offer their unique ability skill trees and are good for their respective combat role.

The combat system is somewhat traditional with a few curve balls along the way. You right click an enemy to enter combat and your character will auto attack. Beyond this are your skills and abilities, these are activated by either clicking the hotbar icon or using the corresponding number. You obtain your skills and abilities two ways, first you have a set amount of class abilities that you can unlock and upgrade through levelling. Secondly, the weapons and armour you use will also carry both active skills and passive abilities. This means that if you change your weapon you can end up with different abilities and this can change your play-style to some degree.

Questing in the game is very text book MMO, go to quest giver, do quest, hand in and move on. That being said I like how some of the quests tie into the games crafting which I'll go into in a moment. There’s plenty of questing content to go through in villagers and heroes in fact there's over 1000 quests and the storyline of the game plus it's expansion the fury of the stone lord is a fun story to go through.

In zones and dungeons on top of your run of the mill enemies and bosses, you also have bounty enemies. Bounty enemy locations show up on your minimap and offer great rewards, even better they are soloable. Meaning you don't have to miss out on the XP, gold and loot that bounties provide. Speaking of loot, there’s plenty to be had and its a well designed system. Loot from enemies will contain gold, animal parts for crafting, weapons, armour and more. Those who enjoyed Diablo 2 will recognise the name Steig Hedlund, Hedlund was the lead designer on the most widely loved Diablo game, he is also the designer of the item, loop drop and crafting system in Villagers and Heroes.

In my opinion the crafting system is one of the biggest draws to the game. There are 10 crafting professions: Fishing, Mining, Bug Collecting, Plant Lore, Woodcrafting, Smithing, Cooking, Tailoring, Gardening, and Ranching. Gathering resources is simple and straight forward, simply find a node be it a mining node, fishing spot etc and flesh it out. Nodes also have levels, so as you level your proficiency you'll be able to mine higher level nodes for higher and rarer materials.

There’s also Gnomenting with is short for gnomish augmenting, this is the crafting ability to combine crafted gear,elder gear from defeating lair bosses and rare randomly found exotic gear. The developers didn't want to have the most powerful gear exclusive to the end game bosses and wanted to make crafting more meaningful. It allows the player to combine different gear in the way of their choosing. Since about half the spells & abilities come from gear & weapons, this means that some very powerful and unique items can only be created and not looted.



The best thing about crafting is not only the amount of things your able to create but how easy and accessible the whole system is. It's easy to use, easy to get into and easy to progress. While the game is not a true sandbox, it has a lot of sandbox features, crafting feels more of a joy than a painful grind. Also due to the fact that crafting is very meaningful, it means that crafting benefits you overall in the game rather than it just being a separate part.

Another big draw of the game is the player housing and village system. Once a player purchases a property, they become part of that village. Villages are player created and there are two types, open where anyone can join or guild specific. Player housing itself is very customizable with not only the ability to customize the appearance of your house but the ability to both garden and ranch animals in your own land. It means especially those looking for an immersive experience you can live on your own little farm with crops and animals of your choice.

Villages themselves are also not just plots of land, they are upgradable. Villages can be levelled up by members of the Village with better facilities such as a forge and more. Villages can also grow and expand in size by opening up new neighbourhoods providing housing for more players. The developers are planning to push the village feature further in the future by allowing villages to create their own dungeons and having Village vs Village warfare, where by villages plunder each others dungeons for loot, special relics and more.

Now as I've mentioned the game is a free to play which means of course there is an in game store. However its certainly far from being pay to win. The contents of the cash shop are simply cosmetic items and items that provide boosts to things such as resource gathering. There’s nothing that could really be considered as pay to win. That being said the cash shop is a little pricey but there’s really nothing you need to progress or get enjoyment from the game, which is a good thing in my opinion.

Villagers and Heroes is one of those rare games that sure, it's not perfect and its no big budget MMO but what it is, is a joy to play. Its very rare that I play an MMO and don't feel pressured to be doing anything specific, or to be rushing through content. Villagers and Heroes provides a pleasurable gameplay experience. The way the crafting, player housing and village system is designed, it really promotes a sense of community in the game. Playing with other people to complete village projects and more is fun and a enjoyable experience. It's also a game that may well appeal to the roleplaying community as theres housing, crafting oh and chat bubbles.

If your an avid mmo'er who is looking for hardcore PVP or PVE, frankly you won't find it here. However if your looking for an MMO that’s a fun way to spend time playing with people that’s not too demanding on your time and energy then its right up your alley. The game is by no means perfect in any shape but the developers at mad otter have clearly tried to create a community focused game and have crafted the whole thing very well. I would also add that its a mmo that is very accessible to people who haven't played mmo's or are looking for a more relaxed casual experience with a good, helpful community.

reviewText:
i have 456 hours, on the StandAloneClient , i've seen this evolve from a webgame to a game that goes on steam and been with this game since it was born... but steam players play 15 minutes and shout : P2W!!!!  . It's not like that .... the game has  great visuals and humor, lots of questlines and skills, nice crafting and overwall  enjoyable systems.

about the P2W tho,  let's just say that people are not happy with the fact  how your base energy replenishes.
the base energy is called Vim , it is used to craft and gather .  1 vim replenishes in 4 minutes , 1 vim can be used to craft 1 item OR gather something, however you can buy full vim potions that replenishes your vim to the top. Little did the 15 min players know... on daily logins you can pretty easiliy win those potions and you can craft them when you reach certain level cooking.

I enjoyed this game  and i still enjoy it. I'd give it 9/10 i would give it a 10 if there was more voiceacting
*UPDATE*
Gathering no longer takes energy and there is more voice acting now  , they listened to the community and changed it ^^
Also the fact that the devs  are nice makes this game special.
They will listen to any request the players want to see  added to the game.
In these  hundreds of hours spent here, i can say for 100%, there is no better community, everyone will be welcoming and friendly to you, help you learn the basics and run some bounties (bosses ) with you to help you level up and put you on your path.
The path of being either a villager, or a hero.

reviewText: I'll be frank: combat is just bland. It's not bad, not by any length, but there simply is no nuance. You click a mob, press some hotkeys and loot falls out of said mob. Luckily, this game isn't about combat. So far, I'm having a blast with the amount of options presented to me. I can mine ore and make it into ingots ('pigs' in-game) and trade them to my neighbour for some of his or her fine produce they harvested from their garden. I can become a tailor and create garments from the loot drops my more combat-oriented village-mates receive. Oh yes, there is a housing system; you join a village and contribute to the betterment of everyone while also gaining materials and xp. A good example would be Runescape's Clan Citadel system, except the materials you gather go to you and you decide whether it goes back into building the village.\n\nOverall, the game is a fun little timewaster played with friends. Graphics are so-so for an MMO, NPCs greet you in different voiced languages (yay Slovak) and there are plenty of kill-list quests. I recommend turning off click to move - you'll figure out why when you play.

reviewText:
My take on Villagers and Heroes
Pros:
Lots of crafting to do
You can find all the materials you need in the world
Lack of Vim or energy system (removed in past patch. I saw this was a major reason for negative reviews in the past)Cons
Gets boring as you go further in
Lack of motivation to continue with lack-luster storyline
Auction House is empty, I would never be able to make money off of how the player economy is in its current state
Empty feeling community
Many bugsFurther Examination and Review    I have to say, I had some hopes for this game. I've always loved mmos that carry a heavy focus on PVE rather than PVP. When I saw this had a dynamic crafting system, I was quite pleased. I've played Runescape and several other rpg mmos that mimicked the style of Runescape over the years, I figured I would  give this one a shot and see how it hold up. And it did not.

The first thing that caught my attention had to be the lack of ambition this game gave me. In games like Runescape, I was always working towards a specific, achievable goal. I saw all the cool things you could do with construction downt he line, so my goal was to level construction. I saw all of the sick skill capes people earned through their hard work, I figured I could maybe try for one as well! In Villagers and Heroes.... Not so much. I mean even RPGMO had some interesting skills that made you wanted to level and achieve even with the old-school graphics and lack of aniamtions. Villagers and Heroes led me on a wild goose chase throughout the internet to find out what I could do with say, smithing or mining? Is mining a good source of income on the player market? Do I get cool capes or titles or SOMETHING from achieving the highest level? Why should I sit here and grind all day if nothing will come of it?

The second thing that caught my attention was the stale and empty Auction House". This is supposed to operate much like any other player market in any standard mmo. For example in the Grand Exchange in Runescape
date: the economy was always bustling. The demand of the market flowed naturally in a way I was able to take advantage of and profit from. It was fullfilling to find out new ways of making money. In Villagers and Heroes

reviewText:
Villagers and Heroes us a Hidden gem in a sea of Free to play games. Dont be put off by the tutorial this game try's to introduce to you slowly its features and soon you will be chasing bounties or delving into its massive crafting system (a full 70 levels for each profession and gather) The world is truly Huge, 500 hours in and I have not seen all of it yet.

One of the biggest things about this game thet makes it different from the sea of other Free to plays out there is that its crafting system is fully intergerated into the combat system, crafting isnt something just tacked on its a major part of the game system and this isnt truly noticable until much later into the game when you start to look at ability scores and stats and greater detail.

I have also been quite surprised by the sheer amount of Adult players in this game, most people I meet are 20+

One of the major letdowns has been the steam crashes, but the devlopers have been working very hard and getting as much informtaion from the community as they can while keeping us updated (which as you know is very rare in this day and age) I look foward to the very bright future of this game.
voteText: 38 of 50 people (76%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game begins with the designing your character - choose wisely, there is no going back on the customisation unless you are willing to pay real money for it.

The talents and skills you choose to start off with gives you a head start in those areas, but they can be changed as you progress or by using a potion. The choice of house style is far more important as changing house style cost gold, which you'll earn by killing monsters and doing quests. Each style has its own variations and each variation has its own perk, so plan ahead what perk you want for your character. Choose the style in accordance to the perk you want, even if the variation with that particular perk is not available when you start off. You can always buy the variation you want as soon as you have placed your house. Changing one house styles to another cost a lot of gold (120 gold) though, so it's better to choose the right style to begin with and then just buy extra variations to that style, which is cheaper (30-90 gold).

This game does not deserve the bad cred it's gotten. It is constantly being improved on. There is lots of people playing it (based upon playing the EU server) and the community is really friendly and helpful. You can play it on your own but it's a lot more rewarding and fun being a part of a guild.

That you can use real money in the game is not blatantly obvious. It is a fully functioning game for free. Would you like to customise you're character a bit more though, you can visit the shop and buy extra stuff with real money.
voteText: 25 of 28 people (89%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The people who complained about bad customer support and pay 2 win, have obviously not played the game very long or gotten into it.

The staff, devs, and mods of VH are top notch. Have a question about something? Ask in world chat. If no one responds or doesn't know, make a post on the forums. Mad Otter is very relieant on the community so opinions and bug reports and the such are taken into consideration and worked on being fixed. The devs want and need it, to help improve things and appeal to the community. Customer Support is very accommodating and will usually 99% of the time be able to help you out; again, if you don't recieve a response within a day or so, notify a mod or post on the forums and they'll contact a dev to get on it.

The game is def not pay 2 win. They've removed several things from the item shop (including buying gold) that made it seem that way. Ya, there are some items in there that can make the game easier, but it is still possible to play fine without them. If you watch the forums, there are often events that go on, and you can win crowns or item shop prizes from those. The game also doesn't have pvp, so its not like you're going up against other people. Additionally, this prevents a bunch of bratty kids from wanting to play, so the game is pretty peaceful and friendly.

The community is a huge part of the game too. The game is family friendly, so you do not get people flamming others and yelling profanities at everyone just for the heck of it. It also means that the game is not sexualized like so many other games. Male and female gear are basically the same models, so you dont get the huge difference of the females basically being naked and the males completely covered up when wearing the same piece of gear.

reviewText:
I don't know why its taken me so long to write a review on this game, but here goes! (apologies in advance, i can get a bit wordy and off topic, lol)

Okay, so it is going to look like i've not played this game at all, but I have been playing since way before steam, so my account isn't attached to steam.  However my actual play time is over 6,000 hrs via /playtime feature in the game.

Short history, I found this game a few years ago, instantly attracted to its charm.  It is my first of this type, with the crafting mechanic etc in it.  But I have tried several games since and nothing comes close to what i'm looking for in a game as much as this one does.  I did leave (for about a year) because of some graphical/movement update that kind of took me out of the game because, well... I'm not good with changes apparently, lol..  There literally wasn't a day that went by that I didn't wish that I was playing it again, but because the new movement etc was so foriegn to me, and gave me a headache.. I just didn't try.  It took an entire year to make myself try and get used to it, and wow am I so glad I am back.

The game has improved drastically (from what was already a pretty great game).  The new starter area that has been rolled out is impressive, the story line very much intrigues me.  But it isn't all about the story line.  Sure the quests are great, combat is pretty fun (nothing overly complicated but not too simple either), crafting has certainly changed since I first started playing (and changed for the better I might add.. even tho i had no idea it could be improved!)

You could call me a fan boy (or girl would be more accurate) and you'd be right, but with great reason.  This game has such charm to it, the community is great, helpful, and only on rare occassions will you run into 'trolls', etc.  I think this is in HUGE part to the No PVP...  Just because personally, I feel like it can sometimes bring out the worst in even the nicest of people.

To sum it up, this game is really great... So great i find myself skipping work sometimes just because I want a day to relax and play, lol

reviewText:
I've played Villagers and Heroes for just over an hour so far. Based on first impressions, I think I can safely affirm that this is a fine free to play game. While the aesthetics of the art style remind be of a classic Disney animated film (and, in my humble opinion, this is NOT a negative), I find it very pleasing to the eye. The game performs admirably on my gaming laptop, and I have had no major issues.

The gameplay, while mirrioring that of most MMORPGs, doesn't yet feel repetative (of course, my opinion on that may well change as I play more). I find it fun, engaging, and interesting. Talents are easy to use, but vary enough to keep me interested, in and out of combat.

I don't intend for this to be a long review, so, in conclusion, I will say that if you are looking for a fun, engaging, and pleasing free to play RPG, then I believe that Villagers and Heroes could be for you. I highly recommend it to anyone new to the genre, or even a seasoned veteran.

reviewText:
A few days ago this game came out, with the name Villagers and Heroes. It's an RPG with some elements and technics which can't be found in many games. Well the controls aren't great, but it's not a problem. There are many great things to see. The graphics are beautifully animated, and it looks like a cartoon. The shaders aren't bad as well. But let's speak about the gameplay...

There are 4 classes: Warrior, Mage, Hunter and Priest, and they have they'r own unique skills. You can craft things, from materials which you need to gather, and the crafted items are better than those you find sometimes.
Theres even a portal to Villages, where you can buy a house. Theres a limited number of plots in a village, but it's awesome. You can design your house the way you want, and you can make a farm behind it. A house costs 20 Crowns, (Crowns can be bought with real money, 20 Crowns = 1,46 Euros i think) but it's worth it. In a village you can find every material.
Now about the gathering and the crafting system...  There are lots of crafting and gathering activities, and each of them has it's own level. So if you mine ores, you get 100XP if you find some, and for some XP you get lvl-ed up, and you may get better ores.

I think this game is pretty awesome, it has some bugs, but it's a new game, updates will come and it will be better. I would give a 7/10 for this, and not because the graphics, it's the game itself. (Graphics can't make a game awesome, only a bit better, it's the gameplay, and the mechanics what a game needs)

Forgot to mention i played hundreds of MMOs which are more worse, so give it a try!

reviewText:
I love playing this game.  I waited several months before reviewing to make sure I get the full experience.

Firstly, the game is always changing.  I'm not even talking about different lvls and such.  The developers really listen to suggestions to make the game better and they do make fixes to go along with those requests.
As far as lvls go, there are plenty of bounties/maps/monsters to kill at each lvl.

I do love how you can either play solo (with the occasional group for harder bosses) or join a guild, you don't have to do either.

If anyone says it's pay to win, it's not.  It's easier if you pay for certian, but you can do it without spending a penny.

reviewText:
For anyone that has any experience in playing video games or especially MMOs, I do not recommend this game.

Graphics:  The photos  look much better than this game actually looks in game.  For the most part it is large empty spaces without much in the way of adventure.  The coloring is very cartoonish with little to no texturing.

Story/Quest Lines:  The story can be rather humorous, however the generic grinding system leaves one rather bored.  Combat can be really buggy.  Mobs sometimes don't aggro immediately.  When ignoring mobs and running away, they will eventually drop aggro but will suddenly come back.  Mobs will sometimes randomly respawn immediately after killing them.  While testing out the archer my auto attack would randomly just stop and I'd have to attack, again to get it working.  Very buggy.

Crafting System:  The crafting and gathering is even more boring, as one can pick from the same tree until you have all of the materials that tree or resource supplies that is needed.

If you are of the younger generation of gamers and have little to no experience with MMORPGs, this would be great for beginners.  Possibly recommended for children (maybe 8 and under) - not recommended for pre-teen to adult.

reviewText:
Good craft, decent graphics, clever management and stories, large action freedom. People who made this game have thought a lot. And yes, it is non violent and non sexist, with classic music ambience :)
Really, you will enjoy to play this game if you're not PVP adicted and if you seek a  smart and no-grinding craft game.
And it is free, try it.

Nota : at level 16 in crafting/gathering you will be granted of an energy (VIM) bar : the famous action bar of many facebook-like games.  If you're a full time gamer, you will quickly solve that problem : you will create another or two other character specialized in a few skills. While one is refilling his energy bar for woodcrafting or tailoring the other is exploring maps and emptying his energy bar gathering. There are other ways to gain VIM : gardening, events, management of your leveling, tokens in Gorge; etc
If you're lazzy or have few free time , you could simply spend all your vim in 2 clicks, focuse on village tasks or on mob chasing.

My last explaination lead me to the conclusion : H&V is not a fast leveling pvp game and will attract merely mature players. Or younger ones without blood thirst. This fact explain why community is so peacefull, helpfull and ... well, nice. (at least in EU server, héhé)

Wow.. Just Wow.... When I first seen it in the store I was like.. Ha... Not even worth a minute of my time. But I've been looking for an MMO and I figured... WHY NOT its only like 800MB... There are a few big problems I have with this game

- microtransactions
- horribly, HORRIBLY clunky
- obviously incomplete (bow string sounds when hitting something with a mace for example, I mean, what even)

The game requires a significant investment of time, and I really can't bring myself to put any time into a game that to me, looks like it has no future

reviewText:
So far the game seems to be nice after playing for a few hours, i finished the tutorial missions and the game seems to open up more now. I first thought I had to pay real money to get the licence to own a house, but you will get it if you do simple quest.

Fighting seems to be way to easy so far, but it's just low level and will probably get more difficult later on. The controls feel a bit clunky, but I can live with that, just something I have to get used to. The different skills and professions seem to be more entertaining so far than in similar mmo's like WOW.

As for the size of the world I cannot say anything yet, but looking at the world map it seems big enough. It's not as open as WOW but all the zones are connected through portals. For a free to play game I would definitely reccommend this game so far. Stuff you have to pay for is mostly cosmetic and for your convencience, so no pay to win here.

I would suggest everyone to at least finish the tutorial until you get to the city and to villages to see the potential of the game. Because it may look a bit dull at the very beginning.

I do like the friendly community so far and the Dev's have already addressed some of the issues the game has and people complained about, like not being able to attack while moving and they are currently working on it. Good to hear.

And I do like the art design and cartoony looks. I don't mind that the graphics are a bit outdated as I am playing on an old laptop, so this serves me well I can play this with decent fps.

reviewText:
Pay to win! Good thing it was free to play, otherwise I'd feel robbed. DLCs for this game seem way overpriced. Glad I didn't get that far or spend any money on this junk.

You've got 4 classes, warrior, wizard, priest, ranger. Ranged classes are it. Combat was just dull.  I played the ranger, pick a target, double click on it, run around while it auto-shoots.

Game gets repetative and boring fast. You spend most of your time gathering resources to make a little bit of cash. Every 5 second you can click to gather 1-2 resources, but usually you get just 1. Depending on the level of the resource you get anywhere from 25-100 exps per resource. Yeah, try getting to level 12 where you need 30k exps in that particular resource. Everytime you pop a level, your exps drop to zero again. Takes for friggen ever to get anywhere. One quest requires you get to level 10 in everything. You have 10 skills plus your charater level. At 5 hours of mostly resource gathering, my average level was around 8. Makes for a really exciting game.

I upgraded my tools, didn't make any difference, still gathered at the same amount, the same items. I really don't find it fun where I have to click for an hour on the same resouce constantly, then move on to the next resource and so forth. Go craft you stuff, sell want you can and go back again for more resources.

Other annoying thing I found was it's only 1 player per resouce. And I don't even see the point of have 5 resources of varying levels, where the only one that does anything for you is the highest level one.

Game penalizes you for not playing! Costs 1000cp per week to have a house. I don't see myself ever getting one.

5 hours of game play and I never ever want to play this junky game again. And yeah, it's a bit buggy as well, sometimes you click and nothing happens. Or you select a target and all of a sudden you're shooting at some other target and so forth.

Atleast it's free, and when you get bored, just delete it, having lost nothing but time.

Just looked at the store page, WHAT trading cards? Where? 5 hours I got nothing.

reviewText:
Why is there no option to cap the frame-rate of the game?

There is no FPS limiter, and no vSync. I have also been unsuccessful with using third-party programs to force a frame-rate lock or vSync.

Seriously. Why isn't there some way to cap the FPS? It's 2014! Why does the game even run beyond 200 FPS? No one has a monitor that runs beyond 200Hz.

I have a pretty beefy computer that can play pretty much everything on max, and this game puts more stress on my system than any other game. Why? Because my damn graphics card is running it at 700~ FPS. They are redundant frames. The game does not need to run at 700 FPS when my monitor only refreshes 60 times per second. I am wasting 640-frames-worth of super duper magical computer power when I play this. Are the devs having a giggle?

I don't feel safe playing this game, seeing every value on GPU-Z at 100%.

The only way I would be able to lower the frame-rate, would be by underclocking my graphics card, but then I am either STILL rendering redundant frames, or I am getting sub-60 FPS.

How hard is it to add vSync or an FPS cap option?


I quite like my house; it's where I sleep at night. I'll play the game again when the devs don't try to set it on fire.

0/10 for now

reviewText:
Villagers and Heroes is a classic MMORPG that has been compared to the likes of Runescape and WoW. While I feel that a direct comparison to these games is less than accurate, I would go so far as to say that players from these other titles will find it an easy transition in terms of game play and mechanics. If you have not played these other titles, you will find that the base mechanics of game play are not that difficult to pick up on, thanks in large part to the games opening quest which serves double duty as a well crafted tutorial. While the game offers many of the traditional aspects found in other games of this genre, it has an acceptable learning curve. The main thing that differentiates this game from those previously mentioned is that it is more casual than hardcore, which results in a friendlier community than the average game of this nature.

Like many other games in the fantasy genre, V&H has a medieval setting in which characters engage in three related aspects of game play. Combat and exploration, gathering, and crafting. There is an additional element of game play with the inclusion of villages. Characters can join join a stand alone or guild village where they maintain a house which grants additional storage, raise crops in their own gardens, and maintain a small ranch which yields components useful for crafting.

Despite being squarely in the middle of a somewhat crowded genre, V&H offers a few aspects that make it somewhat unique. The most unique aspect in my mind is an add on to crafting referred to as the Gnog station. Through gnoging, a character can take existing gear and modify its looks and aspects. They can add and remove the various feats and abilities inherent to gear to create custom gear tailored to the individual needs of the character. Another feature that was added just this past year is the ability for a character to be Reborn" which allows them to reset their combat stats and advance their character with bonuses
date: without the loss of non-combat achievements. My most favorite aspect of the game however does not have so much to do with the game itself as it does the games community. The owners and staff at Mad Otter Games have a reputation for being receptive to their customers
recommended: which results in player driven development. In actual game play
hoursPlayed: a player will find the game itself to be well moderated
voteText: which results in a play environment remarkably free of Trolls and Drama-llamas. Of all the on-line games I have played
helpfulPercent:
Villagers and Heroes has perhaps the most friendly and welcoming community that I have ever encountered.

Read more: http://mm-mysticalts.proboards.com/thread/270/villagers-heroes-revised-01-2016#ixzz3wfpDGkPC


~LL


*Notes:

(1) I played this game for over a year before making a Steam account for it. My client account is my primary account. My hours on record as a Steam player are less than a tenth (at best) of the actual hours I have put into this game. Just saying............ :P

(2) Several updates and improvements to this game since the mid point of 2015 have prompted me to revise my original review. Any review you read for this game made prior to June of 2015 need to take into account the ongoing devolpment it has recieved since that time."

reviewText:
I'm just gonna rate the stuff that truly matters, such as server stability, gameplay, and graphics.

Server Stability 7.5/10: Server Stability is not a large issue but it is A issue. Mattering on what your internet is. Usually I'm working on doing either main quests or side quests and then it takes me back to where i was a second ago and turns me into a different direction. I dont know why that would happen but Im saying that its probably because of server performance.

Gameplay 8/10: When it comes to Gameplay it really matters on where you are and what your doing in the game. Monsters are hard to take down when your 2 levels below it's level and not equiped with any potions. I dont like the main boss that you have to take down at the beggining (Donalda Declancy) with 1800 health and a fast health regen rate as a level 10 boss. I was level 9 when i battled her and it was hard as heck, but another player who was level 11 came in and helped me defeat her. It is really hard to level up but with quests that give you almost 3000 experience its actually smarter to do quests rather than xp farm.

Graphincs 7/10: Graphics arent bad, but not great. The graphics just arent as good as some of the other rpgs that ive played.

Over all my score for the game itself would be an 8/10. I am recommending this game because it is a good game but could use just a little bit of work.

Edit: The server stability is actually ok for the most part, it was just my old internet.

reviewText:
So, after playing the game for a brief time, I wanted to leave a review to help other people deciding. I actually kind of liked the game and I think it has lots of potential.

Yet the main reason I would not recommend this game is because it is a massive grindfest with no enjoyable+ added into it. The gathering system seems to be somewhat okay compared to the crafting system. The crafting system is unbelieveable. Espescially after making lots of digging and finding out the grinding amount I have to do to level up my craftings, the game was over for me. Seriously you dont want to click that much, just no.

Other than the absurd crafting system, the game is very unfinished with unconsistent art here and there. You see really annoying and buggy stuff generally.

As for some pros, I would recommend this game for some chilling with friends. The storylines were really fun and the humor is pretty goodly constructed. NPC voices are also okay.

Generally the game is a 4/10 for me.

reviewText:
I feel like the negative reviews are not accurate. I played this game the first day it came out, and I'm not going to lie, it was very glitchy.

The game is an MMORPG by an indie company, and it's only the first week, of course it's going to be glitchy. They are currently on top of everything, so hopefully the game is all fixed up and clean this up coming week.

On with the review... If you've played and liked Runescape, you'll love this game. It is a skill and stat based game. You do little things to level up every skill possible. Picking apples is a skill, cooking is a skill, fishing, crafting, smithing, all that stuff. You start off on a tutorial island just like Runescape where you can learn all the skills and start a main quest.

The controls feel a bit weird but they are very easy to get used to.

Don't fall for all the negative reviews. Play the game for yourself and see if you like it.

reviewText:
The addictive system of gathering and crafting in Villagers & Heroes was the main draw for me.  Building a character with a wide variety of skills that produce stuff is always fun.  The game does not disappoint; I had a blast harvesting a huge variety of items and it was easy to start making quality gear from what I found.

My problem with the game is with the questing.  Remember back when the first WoW expansion, The Burning Crusade, came out and the quests in the new zones were streamlined and really fun (at the time)?  Remember how awesome Ghostlands was, because the zone rewarded you for completing the quest line and you didn't have to traverse the world to do it?

Well, the questing in Villagers & Heroes is very much like the questing was in WoW, before BC came out.  In short, a pain in the rear.  Its a serious slog to level up via questing here; the interface is not friendly enough to group your quests by zone, and there's some other glitches (missing quest markers) that twerk your day.  You're going to want to purchase some virtual wings (teleport stones) because your feet will be tired from the running.

Despite all of that, getting to level 14 was actually a pleasure.  I may see how far I can get just harvesting and whatnot, but more questing from here on feels like a bad-paying job.

reviewText:
The best thing this game has going for it, besides amazingly pretty graphics, is the community.  It's amazing how well people get to know each other while killing monsters or gathering mushrooms.

There is a lot to do and there is no rush to do any of it.  People can play on their own or in groups, can play a little or spend days playing: there are many choices to fit all kinds of players.  It's worth a try!

(I will mention that my personal experience is that STEAM and V&H do not form a good team- so far- seeing as Steam is holding my password for the game hostage.  So if you decide to get the game through STEAm- make sure to write everything down, otherwise, no one will help you. )

reviewText: So my first play through the game was ok. The quests where the same as any other MMO but thats expected. While trying to kill mobbs other players would always get the first hit and then i would have to wait a couple of mins so i could complete the quest, that was annoying. After about 30 mins i got out of the starter zone and picked up a quest to join a village and get a house. I was expecting something like wildstar where i can place things in the house and move stuff around but couldnt even walk in, it was just a bank, put stuff in and take stuff out. The houseing was dull. Then wanted to look around the villege and was also hoping that it was like SWG and that you could place stuff anywhere but its preplaced structures and you can only upgrade them with other guildies. After a couple of hours of playing it seemed like a ok MMO but I give it a 6/10. For a free to play game its not that bad. Hope everybody doesnt freak out over my view of the game but hey review is a review.  Happy questing everybody.

reviewText:
Villagers and Heroes isn't exactly your typical MMO...
It has taken the crafting and gathering thing to a whole new level of not enough inventory space as well as focused the entire game around crafting and gathering with a hint of PvE. The PvE side exists (I'm still low level) but it's like the crafting and gathering is the main point of the game and the monsters are like a side quest which is pretty weird to say.

The list:
Graphics - Cartoony graphics-ish. They're alright but don't expect RIFT quality.
Gameplay - You mean gathering and crafting? Pretty dang repetitive.
Combat System - It absolutely sucks. Probably why they avoided PvP? Is there even PvP in this game? No there isn't.
Community - Very friendly and very helpful.
Chat System - It really sucks. Should be replaced immediately...
Achievements - Yes of course... and they give you gold as a reward for earning them (interesting).
Voiceover quality - Meh - Some NPC's are great and some others are terrible or too loud/too quiet/bad voice acting.
Grinding levels? - It appears it's going to be quite the grind to get everything from leveling/crafting/gathering to maximum.
Auction house - Very meh.
Lag? - No, not really.
Kid friendly? - Absolutely. Have young ones and need to have them do something for awhile? Let them play this.

Overall it's an alright game but wasn't what I was expecting.

reviewText:
This game has A LOT of potential. From the graphics giving you that almost old-school feels to the housing & gathering system. I have only played for a couple hours thus, but I am thoroughly enjoying it.

As reviews below said, the combat is not fluid at all, but the DEVs are aware of this and are currently working on making it smoother. The gatherng is a huge load of fun, though. It's quick, easy and exciting due to random drops and the ability to discover new items and objects. You will, however, find yourself right-clicking a little more than you'd hope, IMO.

After a little more work has been done on this game I think it will be a huge success and it is definitely worth trying out. :)

reviewText: Now this may be a very average RPG but for a free to play game, its not so bad. Combat is nothing special and probably could be slightly improved for instance if you move the camera even slightly during combat your player will stop attack and will just stand there. However on the positive side they don't push you to pay real life money and it is 100% playable without playing real life money (as far as I know) which is very good for a free to play game. The auction house is great for getting rid of items you cant use but are of value and the leveling system is fair. Something that isnt in the game however and is in most RPGs is PVP combat. You can work co-oporatively in a boss battle for example but the person who gets the last hit gets all the loot unless your in a party. Anyway overall i would give it a 6/20 because the combat system could use improving, it can get a bit boring and repetitive at times but it is good for a free to play RPG and is decent if your looking for just a simple RPG.

reviewText:
Villagers and Heroes is an amazing game, if you like RPG style; this is a game for you. It is based on fighting to level up and complete quests, these quests can be for different, there are quests for leveling up your hero, (Eg) your player. there are four main player types, Worrier, Wizard, Hunter and Preist.
The Worrier is for heavy close combat fighting. Wizard is for distance, long ranged attacked but not great in close combat same with the Hunter(archer). Finally the priest, it is mainy used for healing but can fight as well. In the game you can go solo or join a party, once you join a party you dont have to stay in it, you can leave it when ever you want. If you are in the same area as some party members you get 50% of the exp they get from attacking a monster.
As you have read already there are areas, in Villagers and Heroes there is loads you can explore you start on a island called Ethlos this is where you willl be given a main quest, you do not have to do the quests but it is recommended if you want to level up fast, also the main quest is only to help you level up when you first start and teach you the rules and the ways around the game. Once you have completed it your done with the main and can do side ones.

You can also join a guild or a village these can help a lot as if you need something Eg (Ore) for smithing you guild or village has a vault where players can put equipment they dont need in it for others to have, the differents between a guild and a village is that you can join a village of the bat were a guild the leader has to accept you in the only way this is done is if the leader invites you.

Once you are in one of these you can make a house as you go on in the game you will unlock new looks; their are many looks out there also you can farm and breed this is a good way to make money, Money is in copper, silver and gold. 100 copper = 1 silver and 100 silver = 1 gold. monsters drop around 8-15 copper so the best way is to farm or quest. You can also get money from doing achivements.

If you realy want to get good stuff level up fast or get money fast you can do in game purcheses but i dont recommend this, but its your money.

Im going to stop talking now as i will give away to much and this may stop people playing as they know most things about it.

If you need help on the game or want tips or if you have any questions just add me and message me, i will try to answer back as soon as i can

Hope you start playing its a great game, you nevere know we might be able to fight together.

reviewText: V&H is a very fun, engaging game in which you can focus on crafting and farming if you are not particularly into slaying monsters. Great for a day when you need to power down and not think too hard. The world is immersive, and allows for communal game play. Looking forward to this game's evolution, building on its current success.

reviewText:
I haven't played this game very long so take my review with a grain of salt. This game is very charming. It reminds or of Runescape a little.

PROS
- Crafting/gathering system seems very deep. You have smithing, mining, foraging, cooking, tailoring, wood crafting, fishing and bug catching.
- Player housing. You get to customize it and gain different benefits from doing so. You also gain the ability to grow crops and the ability to raise animals. Once you own a house you get the option to join a village or create one of your own. Villages can hold 35-60 player houses and you will gain benefits the more houses you have in a village.
- It doesn't seem pay to win so far.
- Its charming. It doesn't take itself very seriously.
- Unique backstory creator at the beginning
- The download was just under 1gb

Neutral
- The combat system is decent.
- The graphics aren't bad. Cell shade-y.

CONS
- The voice acting is hit or miss.
- Seems too easy so far. Tank and Spank warrior has no trouble with enemies a few levels above him.
- Some of the quests seem bugged. You're told to go somewhere but the quest wont update.
- Very limited customization of your characters looks.
- Only 4 classes with 2 different playstyles to choose from per class.
- I didn't see many people in the starting area. Maybe 4. (1:30 AM) Not sure if its because of me being in the starting area or not.

Overall the game is a 7/10. Its fun and a small download so if you're curious about it I would recommend you giving it a shot! :)

reviewText:
If there was a maybe button, thats what I'd reccomend.
Pros : Its very Runescape-esque.  Which I entirly love.  I love to farm and craft, etc.  I could spend all day just farming and crafting and the next day go beat the living snot out of that Bounty Mob that killed me the other day.  In that respect, Its great.

Cons : Only problem is, the graphics are a 3/10 at best.  I have been spoiled by many games that are high demand video hogs.  So, this is more of a personal preferance.  Out of the few hours Ive played, The game window has closed 5 times with no warning at all.  Getting stuck in a wall was a pain.  Also the in game village building.... Is always full.  Almost impossible to start your own or settle in one already made.  There is in game purchases which make it slightly P2W, but its almost needed at times.  If your a crafter, the bag space you have is very limited.  IIRC its 2 16 slot bags.  Others you need to buy through in game purchases.

Overall a 4/10.  The Runescape end of it keeps me playing mainly because I've been hankering for a nice MMO RPG to play thats not mainstream.  IT IS F2P at any rate.  Worth a try.

reviewText:
Villagers is a less complex mmo with alot of crafting and 4 class combat system.  Quests are centered around kill so many of this , deliver that, gather so many of these, etc... There are some multi phase quests which continue over several zones and probably levels which add to the flavor and enjoyment. Mostly its a very friendly PVE game with a alot of crafting.
The developers are constantly updating the game with different event zones which pro rate the characters by level so that all can group on more or less an even ground.

Exception  recently customer service has been extremely slow and you are much better off getting advice from the world channel if they can help which is true with most problems

my latest interaction with customer service has taken over 3 weeks and still no solution in sight

reviewText:
Graphics (indie) 8 of 10
Entertainment value 6 of 10
Pay to Win: Yes (money speeds up leveling and gets more skills to play with)
Pay to Play: No (no money needed to play the game)
Stability 9 of 10 (only had a few minor issues nothing game breaking)
Controls 10 of 10 (very easy to understand)

This is everything I've been looking for in a game except the f2p pay shop crap.  You get to have a town.. you and many others build houses in this town. you get a farm that you planet, water and grow.  get a ranch for raising sheep/chickens and other things.  in your town you build all the crafting machines (and upgrade them), build the collecting stuff too... like mines/trees/fishing holes... and the material is stocked by using a few items from the real game (apple tree level 1 takes 20 red apples to fill it and then it contains 200 for you to harvest in your town (the apples you get from town can't be used to refill this)

PROS:
Can build your own town with all your friends (in a guild or not up to you!)
Can craft weapons and armor
Can play how you like.. wanna just do crafting and nothing else after the tutorial do it.. your friends can bring you 20
of any material (ore for example) load it into the towns ore supply and boom you can now mine 200 of that ore
type.
Though it does have a real money shop, it does seem to not be required to play
CONS:
In game real money shop (no matter what this is never a plus in my book, even though this isn't required so it's in the
pro column also)
Sockets, You get a handfull free that's it.. then it's pay or do without.. what are sockets? they are the attrib of your weapon that gives you your attack skills.. without them you have to pick do you want slow shot or poison shot or one of 5 other abilities you can only have 4 without them.
Game is entertaining for bit but then becomes extremely time killing.. ex: at level 21 you need 120,000 xp to level a craft.  you only get 100 per tree (without any xp boosts, I'm getting 106 in town) so just to get to 22 in gathering you'd have to click a tree/bush/mushroom 1, 200 times. (good luck)
PAY TO WIN - you can buy things with real money and speed up your leveling .. one guy hasn't bought much been playing 1200 hours and he's only level 54(out of 75) other people have paid for stuff and made it to 75 much faster.
EDIT: 36 hours in .. completely bored .. there isn't a point no direction can't figure out what's the point.. crafting is good for a while but honestly there is no point cause the gear you find in the wild is better than anything you can craft.

I keep this as a recommend because if  you like crafting and gathering games this one is pretty good for about 30 hours of entertainment .. which is more than I can say for most games I've paid $50+ for

reviewText:
Gave this game a good hour of my time before I gave up. Why?

Was it the sub-par graphics? No. I can live with graphics being basic, but they are styled to something I'd expect in an MMO about five or six years ago.

Was it the vast emptiness? Also no. While I was on there were NO other players on at all. So these vast villages and towns felt... dead. But even then, I prefer single player games, so I can live with that.

Was it the bugs and massive lag-spikes? Yes. Falling through the terrain became all too commonplace. Several times I would spend five minutes running a metre due to a lag spike forcing me to re-run it. Also, why so much delay between acknowledging I've hit attack/move/speak/craft/open menu (it makes a sound and graphic when you do) and actually performing that function.

So why the immediate hatred for this game with just a few bugs? The truth is that there are far better free-to-play MMOs out there that nailed down the basics before they decided to get all fancy (Neverwinter, Rift, DC Universe just to name three). Yes, the player controlled villages was a cool idea, whilst every game needs a hook, you should always make a game PLAYABLE first.

Players will forgive an average game that has a good (if somewhat buggy) hook if the basics are playable. Why? They'll stay long enough to give the developers a chance to streamline the hooks.

Players will not forgive a subpar game that has a good hook if the basics are buggy? Why? They'll abandon it before the developers actually improve the game engine.

reviewText:
One of my favourite games of all time. Villagers and Heroes is unique yet it got alot of common to other mmo's and mmorpgs. If you've ever heard of Runescape and you liked that, then you will DEFINATELY love this game. It's addicting and the quests never get boring!

You can choose classes, whether it's a priest, wizard, warrior or a huntsman. Ofcourse, the warrior uses swords and the huntsman uses bows, and the priest and wizard uses spells and such. You can level up your mining, smithing, woodcrafting, ranching, gathering, plant lore and MUCH MUCH more! And there is one more thing, when you level up the certain skill you get to be able to do other stuff with the skill! Me personally love mining, but that's because I love having money. Mining is a great skill if you want some quick money.

Also, you can make your own house with your own unique pets and gardens! How cool isn't that?!

The game is free, yes, but there is still an option to pay to get special perks, however, you're not obligated to pay one single cent to enjoy this game. If you're interested in using real money you can buy boosts and such, but every game has that feature. You can also buy cool clothing.


9/10
*Excellent graphics - With the option to change them to your liking
*Great community - Everyone, or atleast almost everyone is helpful and kind, really a good place to have a good time!
*Antihack/cheat - The developers made it sure that it would be absolutely no cheats or bugs what so ever, and if they ever find one they will fix it at the second

I love this game and I hope you will give it a chance too!

reviewText: The idea of the game sounds great, however after playing awhile I just couldn't keep going. The animations are terrible and turning in this game using the WSAD controls is dreadful. I'm not sure why the game defaults me to use WSAD controls when they doesn’t even work properly. Also even the NPCs speak to me in a different language majority of the time or have a strong accent. It makes for a very awkward environment, emphasizing that the game isn’t very polished.\n\nThe game is also P2W. Even though there isn’t PvP, paying customers get a huge advantage like better items for gathering, socketing weapons, ect. As for respecing your skill points, you can do it with real money or in-game currency. That may be good for some people, but personally I think it should be completely free.

reviewText:
It's basically an almost entirely better version of WoW.
Pros
-Graphics are pretty nice, especially since the game is somehow less than a GB?
-A tiny, but dedicated player base
-You can master all skills and professions available-- rather than just having to pick two or three.
-Player housing utlilites that is set in a community village
-The maps are large, but don't feel sprawling.
-Insanely nice player community. I don't know how, but somehow it happened.
-Max level is 75, and that takes a good while to achieve.
-Its free!!? all the way

Cons
-Combat is a little clunky
-Only four classes to choose from (though they have different branches)

There's no PVP, but I wouldn't call that a con. Its nice to be able to walk around without getting killed repeatedly.

reviewText:
So this is my experience, it's a bit harsh but this game is just frustrating from the controls down to the usage of system resources.

Controls are terrible, couldn't stand to play the game much longer than an hour. The graphics aren't even that amazing and the use of system resources is horrible. I play every game out there on max settings and I was seeing massive framerate drops doing something as simple as turning my character, which brings me back to the terrible controls. Movement is slow, rotation sucks and the whole layout of the movement in this game is backwards. The character modeling is terrible and I had to restart the game oh...about 10 times because it crashed every time I tried to finish my character creation, once I got through the terrible character creation screen (Which is about 85% of my time spent on this game) I was met with the disgusting control mechanism, I spent an additional 10% of my time playing around with graphics settings hoping to baby jesus that somehow they control the ugliness of the modeling, once again was met with disappointment when the models got even more jagged and I could now see (in detail) how terrible their collision checking was for their AI.

As I turned my character I was met with the terrible disappointment that for these sub-par graphics somehow I am going under 60 frames per second when I can run way more gorgeous MMO's on ultra quality without any issues. This game is a huge disappointment and I feel bad for anyone who wastes money on the in-game content, their global chat is next to dead which goes to show how many people don't want to play this game, because it's bad. I don't even care how many downvotes this gets me, because wow, just wow this game is so bad, please just stop developing this game because the team who handles your coding must still be in highschool. Uninstalling immediately and never looking back to this dark moment in my past. I am going to write this one off as a skeleton in my closet and I am genuinely a little disturbed that a game like this made its way onto the steam market.


YOUR GAME IS BAD AND YOU SHOULD FEEL BAD.

*Edit as of 11/26/15

This game is still bad but I want to add that my specs are as follows:

Windows 10 64bit
Intel Core i7 5820k (6 physical cores 12 logical)
16GB DDR4 SDRAM (2133MHz)
NVIDIA GeForce 970 (3.5GB Dedicated VRAM)

The reason for adding this is so you can all understand I have a machine that is capable of running just about any new release to date on maximum settings, 4K Resolution, etc. without a problem.

Anyway don't play this game, because it's STILL bad, clearly the developers have not listened to anyone or have completely abandoned support for this game. Personally I can't blame them, I would abandon my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ stepchild too.

reviewText:
So far, I quite enjoy the game.

I like how there is no pressure, friendly chat, and other players are quite helpful. To enjoy the game, you really need to love crafting and gathering, two things I have always enjoyed in other MMO's I have played.

If PvP is your thing, there is no component of it, that I have seen yet. The game tends to inspire co-operative play. The mechanics are sound, not to glitchy.

All in all I give the game two thumbs up.

reviewText:
Hoo boy... We got some bases to cover here... Well get out a comfy seat we'll be here a while.

VIllagers and Heroes which I played for around half an hour is... Terrible... Just terrible.

Graphics are pretty advanced and would compliment the game if the game models weren't super low poly and over all just clunky, its something pulled out of a N64 game essentially.
Game Mechanics aren't really based around combat so if you like to so EVERYTHING other then fighting, this may be for you, you run around collecting items, running quests but for god sakes, look out for the combat its so bland and uninteresting.
The voice acting and running animations make me feel like I'm in a bad spin off of some other game, like it was ported over to english but not properly.
EMPTY! When I mean Empty, I mean, I was in a server for about 10 minutes before some other guy ran passed me, the lower areas are either just, not really populated or dead altogether.
Game textures, there is a certain WoW feel to how well the textures are, the modeling sure sucks however the textures are rather pleasing and still very satisfying to look at.
Game Music, following along the steps of some of the better MMOs they use instrumental/orchaestral music, when you start off the game gives you a deep beautiful symphony of walt disneyesque music, it felt like I would come acrossed the 7 dwarves cottage and then have to fight malefescent to save the sleeping princess (I know they are two different stories)

The two main points you need to know,
Everything but the game music and textures sucks
If you feel like torturing yourself, give it a short playthrough (you'll never get your life back)

3/10 - I've had worse

reviewText:
Villagers and Heroes is a fantasy RPG with similar game mechanics to World of Warcraft, Runescape, and Star Wars: The Old Republic. It was released on April 17th, 2014, and published and created by Mad Otter Games, and are also well known for The Red Baron Pack. They have had an uneasy track record, and The Red Baron Pack has gotten a mixed reception, and this game is no different.

The combat isn't anything new, it's basically the exact same as most RPGs. A real-time combat game with abilities, stats, and classes. While it isn't refreshing or new, it is at least somewhat decent.

The controls on the other hand are absolutely horrible, I keep going in random directions, falling off cliffs, and doing rolls without meaning to.

The graphics are decent. They aren't spectacular to say, Star Wars: Battlefront 3, or Destiny, but they are similar to World of Warcraft and Runescape's graphics.

This game is a literal grind-fest. You have to go between Point A and B, but the crafting and gathering system is decent and well put-together.

The community is very good. It's not amazing, but it's actually somewhat helpful and if you want a good community, this is definitely something you're looking for.

The story is repetitive and dull, it's incredibly lazy and horribly written.

Final Verdict: 6/10, Slightly Above Average

What I did enjoy of the game was crafting of Weapons, Homes (Only if you had joined an Alliance) ... That's about it.

The game is pretty much PvE... Pretty boring.
I thought it was going to be an Albion duplicate.

reviewText: Villagers and Heroes has fantastic concepts and ideas. I love the idea of city building with friends in an MMO setting. I was so excited to play this game. I mucked throught the first 45 minutes of wandering tutorials and rough quest dialogue with the light at the end of the tunnel of being able to make my own town with my friend. After beating the tutorial boss we were given the quest to begin the main quest line. NO MENTION OF HOW TO CREATE A TOWN. If that is the main focus of the game, instead of giving repetitive quests and gather missions (Which every MMO does) focus on the thing that makes Villagers and Heroes unique, city building sandbox MMORPG. That is what makes this game a fantastic idea; however, the developers fail to capitalize on the fantastic ideas, instead bogging the player down in childish graphics and incoherent quest line. I would be elated to return when the focus is MMORPG sandbox city gameplay as opposed to standard ♥♥♥♥♥♥meplay.

reviewText: Okay, I am a big mmo guy. So i saw this game and started playing for a few hours, i saw it had some issues but I thought it had potential. I needed a game to play until wildstar came out at the end of May, so i gave this game a real shot. I REALLY tried to like this game. I even put a fair amount of money into it. This game is definately pay to win. If you dont spend at least 50 bucks upgrading your bags, vault storage, and infiniate travel runes you will not enjoy this game at any stage. Which is fine, I was willing to put up some money to see how its end game was. Bad idea. This game is limited to just running around a few zones at end game. The zone is basically the dungeon in which you have a few bosses to kill. Thats it. Thats the end game. No pvp at all. No real instanced dungeons. Forget about raiding. The zones are also very small when compared with other mmo's. Do yourself a favor and do not try this game out for yourself to see if its any good, I already tried that. Its not.\n\nMy suggestion, if you want an mmo. Is to pre order wildstar. Ive put over 100 hours into it and its AMAZING. Great PVP, hard end game PVE raids/dungeons. Warplots (think guild wars 2 keeps but instead of defending your keep with arrow carts you defend it with missle guided lazer systems and raid bosses). Good luck guys.

reviewText:
The game even though lacks a bit of graphics has a great potential to maintain at top. Despite having low traffic channels it seems to me that people are bored to explore the game... everyone complaining about the Vim being inadequate..i say start your day with 20-25 bounties and the vim is enough (you get 40-50 more). A very good feature in the game is the village where simply...money talks bul!sh!t walks. Everyone would want his settlement to be one of the best in game but this comes to a very large price. Endless hours of farming to build the projects but you get rewarded as daily quests appear. Plus you have kitchen, smith, tailor in a convinient radius without searching every city.
I personally enjoy this game very much. I would compare this to Aion but a lot more Gbs and graphics. Huge craft radius, lots of areas to explore but server balance is.... :S .I agree with you people saying that V&H is Free-to-Play/Pay-to-Win.
It is funny though and enjoyable :)
F@cking YES from me

reviewText:
I honestly don't get why everyone is not recommending this game. Sure, at first it's a little hard to get used to, but once you DO get used to it, it's very, very addicting. I absolutely love this game! The only cons of it is that

#1. Monsters are easy to kill
and
#2. I can't play with certain people I want to play with

But otherwise those two things, I love it. I recommend it because it's a good game, and people are not recommending it for no reason. Everybody has an opinion, but I bet people don't really take the time to get into the game.

reviewText: I recommend this game because it is similar to pirate101, wizard101, and School of Dragons. If you like any of those games you would love this! the music goes with the game, plenty of quests to do, and really hard bosses! Well not that hard, but still they can be pretty hard if you don't level up properly. I like how you get to mine, fish, farm, ect. to make certain stuff. I likethe graphics on this game. Very good community. However, only one person gets the quest if ur beating up a boss with a friend or some random person. It takes probs a minuet or so for the boss to respawn. The two servers i played on were pretty full just be aware of that. You can also pick from 4 different types of classes, knight, archer, priest, or wizard/mage.  Each class has a beginners, non-beginners, and advanced clothing looks.

A FUN ALPHA BUILD!! (many bad programing errors and feutures that are not polished yet)

I played this game today with my wife for some fun, to enjoy a nice MMORPG. At first look it is great tones of stuff to do, open world style mmo (you dont have to do anything more than the tutorial to do things) and it was quite fun for the first hour.

I encounted many issues, mainly with programing. The game works but there is many Hacks" in the program
date: that can and will be exploited if not fixed. (Hack as in a way to program something in
recommended: not the right way leaving it open to be exploited
hoursPlayed: not expecting it to be exploited). It also casues load issues and in some cases can cause system to crash.\n\nThe tutorial needs to be worked on and as it sits it is great

so to Wrap this up

FUN 8/10
SYSTEMS 5/10 (NEEDS WORK NOT POLISHED)
STABILITY 2/10 (MANY HOLES NEEDS PATCHING)

This game is playable
