reviewText:
Not played much, quick few things about it so far in my short time of playing..

Bad:
. Optimisation is kinda crappy, It has 99% usage on core 0 on a 4670k oc @4.1ghz and that is it,
. Probably requires an ssd but notice it runs choppy as hell in the intro scene and in the game, you might want to turn the distance settings down to about 70% on the sliders for the quality, view and shadows, maybe view a bit further down and lod down a bit also it wasn't maxing my gpu at max settings just it ran more stuttery.
. Graphics are kinda poo for the character models, well they really do look horrible, graphics overall is okay but not amazing just old.
. Not sure whether bad or not but pretty much like the next runescape.. When runescape used to be a thing this is now that thing or it should be.
. Map useless for quest system

Good:
. Proper Free to play not pay 2 win ♥♥♥♥♥, obviously if you want more bag slots or w/e then that will require actual money but so far its been good doesn't feel pay 2 win at all.
. Gameplay is like any other mmo in a way but less irritating stupic annoyances of fetch quests than final fantasy a realm reborn. Obviously there will be some to do but not all are and some of them that are help you get stuff you may actually need. no spoilers also not sure i haven't been paying attention to much to it i just click on people with icons and now i have a ton of quests to do
. Runs on Potato pcs just remember to give your cpu an overclock if its not doing too good.
. Feels like a next replacement for runescape or it should be the hype that runescape used to be.
. Graphics do suck but they are clean and the cartoony style is actually ok and makes it bearable to deal with.
. So far a lot of gameplay for not having paid money.
. Not a huge download size

Seems worth the time in it so far.. No idea what all the people are thumbs downing it for its better than a few games i have played recently archeage being one of them.

reviewText:
Played 10 levels--will probably not continue.

Not really f2p if you want to enjoy yourself.  The game relies heavily on crafting and combines multiple crafting disciplines involving many different items and then they severly limit your inventory.

So if you're going to pay to enjoy a game, is this the game you want to play?  It's okay and I'd even pay a little for a fully functional version with about 4x as much inventory/storage space, but as is there are better options for the price.

reviewText:
TLDR: Over priced items and a game that doesn't operate properly.

Once you finish the newb Island and start tring to do quest in other areas the game falls apart, Unable to get quest (due to NPC not responding when targeted/mouse clicked), this also happens when you try to click a door.  The main disappoint for me is the over priced cash shop.  They make sure you'll need plently of bag and bank space and they charge you for it (20-60 dollars for bank and bag space is way to pricey) for a game that is at best worth 19 dollars.

I played two Characters to lvl 14ish and had fun till lvl 8ish when the flaws started to show.


Would not recommend.

reviewText:
tldr: This game has the potential to be very enjoyable, but if you want to get the best expience out of it, be prepared for a bit of a cash sink

The village system shows a lot of promise (if you can find yourself an active village) And it is nice to have your own house (even if it's just a nice looking item store) farm and animal pen. The community are also increadibly nice and it's one of the only MMOs I've played where I never encountered anyone trying to agro anyone.

There is a uniquely high focus on item gathering and crafting which can be a selling point for some people, but like battle exp it becomes difficult to progress after level 10 without a lot of time put into grinding.

The music can be very repetetive but is not terrible and there is a nice hand painted texture aesthetic to the world, which is also pretty huge and full of story quests, daily quests and weekly quests to keep you occupied.

However the world being so large is also what breaks the game for me. While it is possible to teleport from place to place the items used to teleport you are premium items that are difficult and rare to find in game without buying them as extras, I get that as a free to play game they have to make their money somewhere, but for something so vital to the gameplay it seems like a bad direction.

I would really like to reccomend this game because I did have a lot of fun initially with it, but with the combination of game vital premium items and a steep grinding curve after the first few levels I can't in good faith fully endorse it.

Though it is free to play, so if you want to give it a chance it certainly wont cost you anything to see for yourself whether you can get more out of it than I did.

reviewText:
WOW! A really terrible game! It tries to feel like runescape. (If you've ever played it). Slow Framerate. Even at low settings. Atrociously Bad Combat. *Click* Thats all. Theres no need to use your skills. Buggy Gameplay and it gets even more confusing to manage after you spawn in. Your Presented with 20 different things. Horribly Voiced Characters. Lathargic movement. (Btw way terrible Moving system.) This game is dissapointing at the least. There are alot of word that can be used to describe how bad this game is. As a matter of fact. It had me laughing at how PATHETIC EVERYTHING IS!!!

Nothing is special about this game. Its a waste of time. And computer Space. If you wanted better gameplay. Play Wizard101! Yeah thats right! I went there! Incredibly stupid Artificial Intelligence.

The Quests are the worst part! To track it You press J" to open up your quest journal. and hit track quest. And After you're presented with a HUGE Icon of the Quest's Icon PASTED onn the map. Not only that but the Quests are Ridiculously easy!

Hunters are overpowered.And everything else is just... AAAAAAAAGGGGGGGGG!!!! TERRIBLE!!!! My short amount of time may have not given the game a chance. I'll take that.
The screenshots look nothing like the actual game. Models Arent Smoooooth Like expected. They're Blocky and pixelated.

Just... No more! 1/10. Misleading

reviewText: This game did not impress me. The graphics were reminiscent of Wizard 101 but less cutesy. The controls were slow and clunky, combat was point and click with clunky animations and the skills were lackluster and generic. On a whole, at present time there are more MMOs out there that are free and do everything better. This game excels at nothing thus far and isn't worth sticking around for. 3/10

reviewText: I played this game a couple of months ago before I wrote this review. What I remember from my experience of playing this game is this. While I enjoyed the content that this game had to offer, or at least the content until the first city where I collect wool to tailor myself a piece of clothing, what I didn't enjoy was the combat system. My combat playstyle is usually hit-and-run and AOE spells. In this game, while I couls successfully execute AOE spells, I wasn't able to 'hit-and-run' since if I moved after I ordered a basic attack but before my character actually executes it, my character never executes it. I'd recommend this game for what it has to offer, but the combat system could benefit from some polishing up.

reviewText:
I wrote a big ol'review of the game on my blog but I thought I'd put the summary here on steam. If you want to read the full version you can find it here:  The Apathetic Gamer - Villagers and Heroes	[theapatheticgamer.com]

The Basics
Positives
Enjoyable art and writing
Large crafting and gathering system
Useful player houses and villages
Negatives
Object collision issues.
To many base materials that can’t be sold.
Clunky auction house.
Poor inventory controls
When it comes down to it Villagers and Heroes is a  niche game that speaks to people who like to craft. Considering the game was made by a small indie studio the game is rather good. While it is playable and enjoyable there is still a lot of refining that I believe needs to be done. If the premise of Villagers and Heroes interests you then you owe it to yourself to give the game a try.

reviewText: This game did not impress me. The graphics were reminiscent of Wizard 101 but less cutesy. The controls were slow and clunky, combat was point and click with clunky animations and the skills were lackluster and generic. The crafting gave me hope, but it was shot down when this more interactive process caused the game to crash multiple times. On a whole, at present time there are more MMOs out there that are free and do everything better. This game excels at nothing thus far and isn't worth sticking around for. 3/10

reviewText: Great if you want a casusal only log on every few days type of game. At the higher levels 16+ you have to rely on an ingame stamina" system called Vim which makes what would be a ridiculously crafter friendly game into a wait until you have more stamina game. reviewText: This game is a great MMO to play with your friends, and is still fun when you are alone. It is harder when you play alone, but I would still recommend it. I don't like the way the automatic combat system works, but most of the time you are using abilities, so I hardly ever notice. The game also has much gameplay with great crafting, wich can be tedious at times, but still is helpful. There are many places to go, and many, many quests to do, which increase with difficulty the higher level you are. This game also has TONS of gameplay, as long as you work on the quests for xp, which is nice so you don't have to grind. I have at least 35 hours of gameplay or something and I am only level 12 and not even CLOSE to finishing the game or quests, let alone explore all of the areas. There are also many bosses to track down and defeat, which also adds some purpose to the game. Everything eventually leads up to fighting a stone atmy with one of Mallok's apprentices or something, but I am nowhere near the end. I highly recommend this game, especially to play with friends.

reviewText:
Disappointment and Disjointed.

These words best describe a game that had some grand ideas, yet simply failed to deliver. The key draw of this game, of course, is that it combined WoW-ish gameplay, with UO-ish housing and crafting. Unfortunately, it simply doesn't deliver on either.

The graphics, to start with, are low quality as they can get. The coding for the game is obviously not optimized, as even on normal settings, I found myself with only 38 - 40 FPS, on a rig  that can run crysis 2 on max settings, and still get 50 FPS, and skyrim, well, we won't even talk about how great the framerate on that is, even with max settings and numerous graphical improvement mods. Graphics, however, are forgivable, if the gameplay is good. Ultima Online stood on this for years, because of the depth of the crafting system, and the housing system.

Stability was also an issue, at first. For the first two hours, my game kept constantly, and randomly, crashing to desktop without any notice or erorr messages, every two or three minutes, while I was trying to craft things. My guess? I probably clicked a button too fast, and the game's code took offense at it.

One thing that this game -does- do well, is that a good chunk of materials can also be gathered by killing monsters, tying the crafting sections in with the combat sections and, if they had imposed some type of skill cap limit, would have made fighters every bit as valuable to a village, as the villagers themselves. Of course, the draw of the game is that you can decide to either be a villager, or adventurer. In truth, you're simply an adventurer that sometimes dapples in villager-lite actions.

I was extremely excited when I finally got the chance to build my own home and enter a village, even so much that I just went to a random, newly-created town, and built it there. I was intrigued at first, that you had to actually stockpile a specific amount of resources at each node, to activate it.

This quickly turned to disappointment, when I found out that, while you only need to gather 30 - 50 of the resource to stock the node, this stock depleted. Indeed, stocking the node with 30 of an item, seemed to give it 182 charges to gather from, before you'd have to restock the bin again. Which is actually pretty great.

Except that you cannot restock the bin with resources gathered in that village, and you can only gather from your own village. This basically means that there is no purpose to loading a resource node up with any resources, unless you plan on tripling the resource and then immediately camping it to boost your own investment (Otherwise someone else can just steal it from you), or unless you want to use it to power-level the gathering skills of new players in relative safety.

Instead, you're just simply better off going to a random zone, and gathering at one of the nodes that never disappears. The game also claims that you can only gather so much in a day, due to an energy bar limit, but I did not encounter this at all in four hours of gathering, though it would also be another dermit, if I had.

Housing has to be great, however, right?

Wrong. Unlike UO, you cannot enter your house. Instead, the house gives you bonuses to specific parts of your adventurering.. but there's a catch. It costs a lot of gold for even the first bonus. Twenty-thousand gold, to be exact. The other bonuses are even more signifcantly difficult to get, requiring rare items, for very small bonuses. Then there is your little farm plot and animal pen.

My sheep went to sleep within five minutes, and I couldn't even interact with him for three hours afterwards, so I can't say too much on that process, other than the fact that I couldn't add any more sheep, because my sheep passed out and I couldn't tend to him to increase my skill.

Then there's the farming. In most games, you plant some seeds, you harvest them, you get back at least 2 seeds and some crops. In this game, you plant some seeds, you harvest them, you get one crop per seed planted, which, if you get enough skill, you can re-plant once. With level 4 farming, I couldn't even re-plant the level 1 wheat crop I harvested. In the end, it's another situation of something that seemed like a great idea, but was destroyed by bad design choices.

So what's the verdict, then? Do you play it, or do you not?

Well, if you're a fan of runescape-ish games, have a lot of free time, and are a farmville fan, this game would probably suit you just fine. The cash shop, at least, isn't completely in your face, and while I could see storage issues (Which are solved by the cash shop, at not too horrible prices, at least) cropping up at later levels of the game, after gathering and hording everything for four hours, I had no problem with it.

If you're looking for something that lets you decorate a home, really give you ownership of your village, and generally reward you for investing in the village, you'll be sorely disappointed, and I suggest you simply pass this one on.

The developers, for what it's worth, seem to be fairly active on the steam forums, and seem to genuinely want to make a great game. Perhaps, in the future, they will take feedback and process it. With the right alterations, and the proper polish, this game could easily become a diamond, at this stage, however, it is a decidely rough cut.

reviewText:
For those of you who may be fans of Villagers and Heroes, I offer my apology in advance. I'm not trolling. So please hear me out.

According to the System Requirements listed below, it reads:

Originally posted by author:RECOMMENDED:
OS: Windows® 8, 7, Vista, or XP
Processor: Intel® Core 2 Duo 2.2GHz, AMD Athlon™ 64 X2 2.6GHz or better
Memory: 4 GB RAM
Graphics: Graphics card with 512 MB of memory or more
DirectX: Version 9.0
Network: Broadband Internet connection
Hard Drive: 3 GB available space
Now, I am using an HP Pavillion dv7 running Windows 7, with 8GB of RAM, an Intel Core i7 Processor, and an ATI Radeon 6770M dedicated video card. In spite of this, Villagers and Heroes struggles to perform on even the lowest graphics settings. Why is this a problem when I am exceeding the system recommendations?

Taking into consideration that I can run other MMOs like Dungeons & Dragons Online, Star Wars: The Old Republic and World of Warcraft at 1600 x 900 with the graphics settings at medium with no problem, there should not be performance issues. But for me, Villagers and Heroes is somehow unplayable.

- even though the game is supposedly running at 20fps, it looks like 1 frame for every 2 seconds
- Mouse responsiveness is painfully slow
- game freezes at character creation
- no sound

Unless you have money to burn, or a monster gaming rig with an nVidia Titan, save yourself the trouble. Don't download it.

reviewText:
2/10

If you like the mindlessness of runescape-esk skilling, THIS is your game. If you like to pay for your inventory (you get 2 bags, the other 4 you have to either rent or you can buy perm, both which cost real money) this is also your game. If you like MMOs that have poor art, takes massive amounts of video card power to run graphics on medium+ and still looks like crap, pi$$ poor combat (anywhere from 2-4 seconds before you actually use a spell that are instant cast mind you), you get where I am going. As you can see I really have nothing good to say about this other than I've already uninstalled.

Tl;dr-
Poorly optimized.
Poor combat.
Lack of base options for character design.
Lack of character classes.
Pay-2-expand inventory. (Real money only)

reviewText: This game literally gave my computer cancer, the only redeeming factor was ease of uninstallation thanks to steam's convenient interface, I started playing and was immediately accosted by graphics that wouldn't have passed muster on the n64,  some of the worst character designs I've ever seen in a game, and music so mindlessly average they would have been better served to have simply left it out. In spite of all of this I decided to roll a character and play for a while, that was an aweful, aweful mistake. I would like the time I spent playing this back, everything from questing to skills, to combat, to professions was so disgustingly below average I thought I was playing something coded by the makers of Runescape, If 5 monkey coded for 5 years on 5 computers you would have villagers and heroes. Once, the pope downloaded villagers and heroes, played it, and declared satan the clear winner at reality. If you're thinking of downloading this, a glass of bleach may be preferable for an evening's entertainment. Now if you'll excuse me I'm off to set this hard drive on fire to erase the shame of having ever downloaded this.

reviewText:
Feels like a baby runescape. Still half decent, not pay to win which is absolutely beautiful.

But the ♥♥♥♥ing combat HOLY ♥♥♥♥. The combat doesn't seem like an important part of the game initially, but you get thrusted into it just to keep any interesting things in the game.

Why the combat is ♥♥♥♥
1. It is click and wait to fire. Terrible lag makes this cringeworthy
2. Combat levels up like any other skill, but extremely slower than the others. This means the experience ratio compared to say fishing, is way off. Level 1 spot for fishing could get you to about level 10 easy in a bit, getting level 10 in combat takes about 6x that length off level 1 enemies.
3. The abilities run off of high costs so you can't spam if you're a wizard, so you have to wait to go into another fight.


Advice for combat:
1. Instead of point>click>wait, have the mouse as an aim and you can fire off of that, in range of course.
2. Better servers
3. Change the exp ratios


But this game is good, the combat brings it down to a no.

reviewText: This game needs help, it started as a facebook game and it is not much better then that. The graphics are cartoonish but that is an art choice, yet it requires a powerful computer to run smoothly on high detail". Now this game is not for combat
date: it is about the crafting as it is fairly well fleshed out and wasy to understand. Yet the developers found out about this and placed a stopper on crafting
recommended: assuming to stop botting but all it has done is harm the actual player. This is due to the ease of creating other accounts who have no restriction on creating potions to remove this blockade put down by the devs.\n\nNext the lag in this game is atrocious there is alot of skipping
hoursPlayed: getting stuck in objects and being hit by enemies that are no where near you (this is also tied into the "combat" of the game). I did some research and this lag has something to do with the old code from this games facebook days
voteText: but this brings up the games combat system
helpfulPercent: or lack there off. It appears as a turn based combat system at first however it is real time
votesHelpful: its just missing all forms of depth and complexity. All you do is spam combat arts and spells with the occasional auto attack and things die
votesTotal: but each attack has an animation and once the animation is begun it is a guaranteed hit unless a dodge is performed. Except no enemy dodges attacks only players.\n\nThis leads to my playthrough being a hammer fest of the number keys and then spamming the z key when it got too much
votesFunny: but that is also down to RNG it appears as i died many times during a roll. Next up is stats of the character
commentsCount: health and spirit restore way to slow. 40 points a minute out of combat is atrocious
column16: this leads to players waiting for a half hour at higher levels waiting doing nothing
column17: there are potions however yet I can only find them in the pay money to the dev section. Death is meaningless
column18: except for the part where you do less damage and take more for 10 minutes meaning you have to wait (or pay the dev).\n\nNow leveling
column19: i was going to beat the game until I spent about 10 hours grinding exp in an area my level only to find my total exp went up 5%. I had to check my numbers but it is about that
column20: the requirements go up exponentially without the gained exp going up a decent amount. So now i have to wait to partake in laggy boring combat that is worth nothing... so glad i can craft oh wait my bot accounts haven't finished. I gave up and went back to EvE online as it is more exciting\n\nSo we have a crafting game that makes you pay to keep crafting or exploit a bottable set of commands
column23: long waiting between battles and death unless your a healer with a level up system designed by morons. This game needs to be pulled down

reviewText:
Having played enough of this I find the game to be lacking as a whole. The combat is bland and boring. The tried and true method feels half ♥♥♥♥♥. Moving mechanics are clunky..don't even get me started on the jumping..The voice acting is by the most complicated and least worked on..the npcs speak three languages from what I can tell from Oak Valley alone.

Crafting is simple and resources seem endless so lvling it is easy..The graphics with the Cartoonish feel give the sense of a tried freerealms which I played a lot of and miss. Even they look unpolished.

I have ran into maybe a dozen players total..so social interaction is limited. The game has a good concept but the developers have really dropped the ball on this game.

So I do not reccomed this game in its current state.

reviewText: This game has a neat crafting system. It's so incredibly easy to excel. However, when you buy a house in a village you must CONSTANTLY pay rent or else the house will disappear without warning or any way to recover said house. This includes any farming you had done or ranching. I lost everything I was working on in a 2 week span. Most other games give you notice and you pay rent for months. NOT weeks like this game. I mioght recommend this game for a young kid because of the bright colors and easy game play etc, but for the regular gamer I would say no.

reviewText:
This is gonna be a long, in-depth review. While I give it the thumbs up, I do so with a grain of salt, and a very big grain of salt.
But for those of you with TL;DR Syndrom, here is a short summary:  The game has graphics that look bad today, but has a good, nostalgia feel, while also giving a nice digital world look. Its a basic and standard MMO, but lacking in some content specifically, content found in other MMOs.

So, to begin with, Im into MMOs. Personally, I am interested in a social MMO, with different aspects to play. Namely, housing, PvE-content, socializing among the community, dungeon runs, RP especially like a knight (like, wearing knights armour, sword, shield, horse) and some PvPing. Yes, I'm aware VnH does not have PvP, but more on that later.
So, really, once you see the game world, and the store page, you'd think this game is just what I'm looking for, right?

First off, the game is pretty entertaining in gameplay. The quests, while the standard, go gather x amount of this, talk to someone, find this, find that, can be rather interesting and entertaining enough. Crafting, while I'm not a big fan of it, plays a major role in you getting the best gear, weapons, etc.
Furthermore, the community is so friendly that they'd simply all agree to craft you whatever item(s) you need/wanted. So it is possible to rank up your crafts at a relaxing pace.
Classes: Its the usual class system that we've seen in all the other MMOs before:Heavy armoured, melee damage inflicting warriors, the OPed archers, the annoying healing Priests, and of course the-middle-of-all-the-classes, the wizard, who is a rather interesting class.
The game is also not p2w at all. There are ways to get market items for free in drops and your daily Lucky Cards. The gear that takes real money, is simply for looks. It shows it comes with no new moves, attacks, or ratings to suggest buying one would give yourself an advantage in battle.
Storage is a problem, but it is so much better than other MMOs, especially SWTOR and Eldevin. There are literally, 28 vaults you can rent, 3 more bags, and storage conatiners you can share with your other characters.
Ultimately, without getting to the end of the game, I can tell you who the final boss will be. No darklord, no emperor, no stone lord, no evil wizard, witches, dark knights, or anything. Storage will be the final boss. The game should be called Storage Wars, as given enough time, it'll cause you tons of problems. So storage is a big time problem, but the storage you start out with, as well as the free vault, will give you a great start. The rest is for once you travel deep into the game.


Something I would like to see added to the game:
Mini games. Somethin to do to pass a few minutes, earn a few coins, and maybe play against another player, like checkers, chess, duel etc. The games could be simple like, memory, side-scrolling and other such little things, VnH themed! It'd certainly help the game. I'd even be satisfied with that to count as PvP.

Now, for the negatives. I'll list them, then explain. As you'll clearly see, this game is lacking majorly in some content that has become the standard in MMOs:

1.No mounts.

2. No PvP.

Yep thats right. No mounts. Now, it wouldn't be such a big deal to me. I could make do without a horse to ride around on. Majorly dissapointed, yes. But not detrimental to the game.
Now, why people couldn't raise aniamals to ride around on, like horses for example, it would fit in PERFECTLY with the game setting. Ultimately, the game is split into two halves: 50% deals with farming, gathering, and just being a neighbor.
The other 50% deals with setting off on adventure to kill Ai monsters. So, raising a colt to a full grown horse wouldn't just make sense, it would only add to the game's depth, adding to the theme of the community working together to build a world, making it more interesting all around! Even Eldevin, who's mechanics, and graphics are much older than this game, has a VARIETY of mounts as well as also being set in a medieval world.

Next, the PvP. Players love dueling it out on the internet. PvP arenas/ zones/ servers can be found just about anywhere on an online-themed game. So why not here? To keep the the community happy, they say. Well ok, I can try to deal with that. I understand that part. Sadly, it has kept me away from really jumping into the game, wanting to spending money, etc. on it. No pressure Mad Otter. Personally, I think that the lack of PvP is really what has also kept this game from becoming something bigger and being able to compete in the MMO market against the giants of the internet.

Finally we have reached the Big One. Housing. Ok, at character creation (best creation I ever went through on a game!)
So at creation, they ask for your house design. They list a few different styles for the outside of your house look. And, once you reach the capital city, right inside, is a guy named Donald. Who is, apparently, in love with the fact that players can own a house. He gives you a quest to go to any village and talk to his sister. The reward: one title to own a house! For free! You must simply choose the when and where! Exciting, isn't it?

So, after settling down on a spot, I buy my house. First thing you'll see is, that there are DOZENS of outside decoration looks, but they cost real money. No matter though, its just whats on the inside, right?
Long story short, there is no housing. All that hubbub about how wonderful they are? Apparently being able to have an extra vault, with access to all your storage areas, is something wonderful everyone should have!
Scam of the game, I call it.
There is talk they'll add interior housing to the game, but no immediate plans of when and it dont sound like the devs are even working on it as of 11/21/15.
Final con: The moderators. Long story short, they're pretty much the refferee of the chat. Sounds good, right?
Well, apparently, they feel(or have been told) that when there is one or more players who're fighting in chat for whatever, they can threaten and ban, those players from using the chat for a set period of time. Naturally, for veteran players, this would be a serious penalty. For new players, it'd simply drive 'em away from the game. Just my two cents on that matter.

To wrap it up: I'm still not sure how long term I'm gonna be on this MMO. With the lack of any sort of PvP, mounts, and housing, my interest fades quickly.
Beyond that, the game is still nice, nostaglic, DEFINITELY NOT p2w. Some of these p2w reviews feel like a free game means no cash shop and when they see one, its p2w" in their minds. Lol.
I will at least keep playing off and on
date: seeing if the game improves. But for how long
recommended: I cannot say. If another MMO appears to have just what I want

reviewText:
This is a usual MMO RPG, though this one appears to be a bit low-badget. I don't mind the graphics and I can deal with the unoriginal quests, but I couldn't deal with constant lag and the weird character movement. I didn't compare it with major games like World Of Warcraft but I have tried a lot F2P MMO RPG and I can honestly say there are better than this out there.

It has plenty of professions to lvl up and the skills are obtained by items, the items you craft and combine. This is a good twist on the lvl up to obtain the new skill model. The talent tree lacks a bit though, not much to do there. The combat is the basic shortcut but....less. The skill manifestation" is lacking to a point that auto-attack might be more desirable to the eye.

This might happened to me only (maybe my screen settings) but at night (in game) it was too dark. Raising the brightness (in game) distorted the colors of the brighted places and raising the brightness of my monitor was blinding me when the day came. Maybe they wanted to give the real night impression like some other games to prevent to hunt at night easily but waiting for the sun to come up was adding to the lack of interest.

I didn't play much so I cannot say about end game or even how it progresses
date: but it is a game that couldn't make me wanna hit the launch button again.  I do not hate it
hoursPlayed: but I didn't like it either. I believe the word "average" is what best describes it."
voteText: October 4, 2014

reviewText: An extremely generic fantasy MMO marred by a number of technical issues and hindered by limited character customization and very few playstyle choices.\n\nFour extremely generic classes await you, with four different faces to put on your character guaranteeing you end up looking like everyone else. The gathering/crafting system talked up for this game is very generic as well; the steps are get tool, click object, wait a second, get item, go to crafting bench, combine two items, get end product. There's no game to it, it's just another grinding simulation, like Farmville. The character models look goofy but without any kind of cartoony charm, instead just looking stiff and strange like a Sim gone wrong, with too much chin and a weird dead-eyed expression. And it's a quest based game, which guarantees you'll be grinding from start to finish; bring me 10 spider silks and I'll let you progress". The combat system is as generic as you get; click the enemy
recommended: and number keys for skills. As for technical issues
hoursPlayed: the game would not recognize my USB headphones and would only play through the laptop speakers
voteText: and I had to install the game three times because two of those times it crashed Steam and didn't show up in my games list.\n\nIn short
helpfulPercent: this is not one of the better f2p MMO's available and I do not reccommend it."

reviewText:
After  about 10h of gameplay my game crashed  (free play version)
There was a threat  found by my firewall and my anti-virus software highly recommended to deinstall the game.
I was just getting to know my way around the worlds and got my character to do what I wanted.

You really have to tweak your controls to move fluently.
Graphics are okay, but definitely not high def.
And in contradiction to the trailer, you can't be what you want.
If you want to be a farmer for example, you still have to get xp in battle skills.
Not a bad game to play, but there are definitely better games out there.
Wouldn't recommend it to my friends.

This game is bull, reminds me of Arcane Legends(Mobile MMORPG made by SpaceTime Studios, a good mobile game company) This game has some qualitys that remind me of Arcane Legends, but Arcane Legends is better then this garbage, boring. let me just break it down for you
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Gameplay 3/10

Visuals 1/10(these are the graphics of a iphone game for gods sakes)

Npc's 4/10(They speak diffrent languages and there dialogue is so unrealistic)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

there you go, overall its probably going to be a 3, this game is not worth my time BUT i still recommend that YOU try it considering its free, so remember this review but give this game a chance, becuase you should never judge a book by its cover or by peoples opinion of the book itself :-)

reviewText:
Another review by Gaius Julius Caesar

I have found that this game is a enjoyable game with lots of people who seem to play it and enjoy it.
This is different for me however, I find the lag to be allmost murderous, I, at times, thought I would die before the game did what I asked, if I said for the character to move to a different spot it would take many seconds before it even started to move. Loading is okay but the moving around the map is pathetic.
I still do tyr to put up with this game but i do not go on it much, as it requires a lot of patience to use. Patience is not a thing you will find in me when it comes with games like this. So if you have a high patience level then I would say you might want to get this game, but if you don't then do not get this game, you might hate yourself if you do.

Yours Sincerly
Gaius Julius Caesar

reviewText: Write a review for Villagers and Heroes
voteText: 5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText: Playing Villagers and Heroes was a terrible experience. Im not going to talk about the ugly graphics or the bugs and glitches that sometime can be very annoying, or the server lag, that even in a half empty EU server can be an issue. Im going to talk about the bad game design:  There is no looting system, yeah right, NO LOOTING SYSTEM, party loot is ALWAYS FREE FOR ALL, imagine how that can work well in a mmorpg. Quests are the worst designed quests I ever seen, and I did play a lot of games. Tedious as hell, and often barely give you hints about what to do. Crafting looks deep at first, but it is quite boring and a very huge money sink, and the ton of different crafting mats will fill up your storage very fast, forcing you to buy space with real money, or throw stuff away. Spirit regeneration, mana-like power bar that is used by all classes (4) to use skills, is a big pain in the butt, you are probably meant to craft huge stacks of potions, because there is no food or /sit option to bring that regen up. You just stand around watching it ticking up veeery slowly all 3-4 mobs. Someone said it gets better when you level up but no idea how much better it would be. I really wanted to try it for the crafting that looked interesting, but as I seen that leveling it up burns tons of money, making you probably have to grind money for that, I stopped trying.

So after getting over that the game itself feels cheap (basically characters have no feeling of weight about them, same animations for moving straight or diagonally etc,) I was then HORRIFIED to find that the unique aspect that had attracted me to this game in the first place (being part of a village) was inaccessable to me, as all the villages were full to capacity (except the guild villages).

Not for me, im afraid.

reviewText: I tried this game in response to a giveaway of one of the content packs and was pleasantly surprised. I find the graphical style rather charming, cartoonish yet reflecting higher resolution GPUs. I concur with many about the crafting system having plenty of depth, though you should probably get some more inventory slots in order to get the most out of it. I have only played the Swift Warrior class so far, which didn't get very high level wise because I was out leveling my crafting and gathering skills. And man, did I enjoy fishing. My only complaint in the four hours of gameplay is that crafting/gathering items from skill use are automatically picked up but players have to manually pick up items gathered from killing monsters, and these items can fall in areas no seen by players. I looked in the settings but didn't see an option to automatically pick up loot. This option would cut down on the time spent twirling about and searching for that treasure. #featurerequest

reviewText:
A free slow paced MMO based on simple gameplay and horrible combat.

The movement in this game is very sloppy, making you almost laugh at the sliding of players around you. The combat system is also slow and not very fluent, if you move at all, hit a skill by accident or practically do anything while auto attacking, you will completely stop what your doing and the abilities you tried to use will go on cooldown. I can't see how that is viable at any point in the game.

Okay then, I get it. The game is called VILLAGERS and heroes, maybe the crafting and exploration part of the game was what it was all about.. but that was not the case. Finding the materials is very easy and when you go to craft items, the game basically does everything for you. You can walk several feet in a village, gather the items needed to cook/fish/shear/whatever and then go back to the area, pick what you want to make and then sit back and watch your guy do every for you. How is that fun? I was hoping a minigame or something interesting to do while cooking or say you had to hammer weapons or armour at a blacksmith? wouldn't that be more fun than watching your pixels stir a pot of apples?

So at this point in the game, the combat is sluggish and outdated, the movement is awkward, the quests and zones are way to linear and the crafting/socialization of the game is completely simple and dead. I really don't understand what the appeal is.

A and D turning should of been improved, and when you look at players moving, they tend to slide due to sluggish movement design. I've asked several people in game and they feel the same way.

And why are the quest givers speaking in atleast 3 different languages when I am set to english?
I understand its in beta, but I fail to understand why i'm being spoken to in english, russian and german.

This game is still in its early beta, so these things could be fixed and upgraded before it is fully released, but its really hard to endure even an hour of this when you have experienced quality games like World of Warcraft and other MMO's.

(Thats not to say its complete garbage, as the forementioned games are subscription based and have time behind their backs to master the this subject of gaming.)

The small player base, having only several players in any given area, makes the chat dead and empty, accept for the occasional moderator snooping around, dropping filter hammers on your head.
On that note, I said crap" in chat
date: and I was told to not use curse words or I should leave the game. Clearly
hoursPlayed: which is a huge turn off for me.\n\nI do however

A boring, casual MMO with everything you'd expect.

Processor: Intel core i7 at 4.0 ghz 8mb cache and 4 cores
